intro: Coccoloba uvifera, commonly known as the sea grape, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean and parts of Central and South America. It is a member of the Polygonaceae family and is characterized by its palmate leaves and small, clustered white flowers. The plant produces edible berries that are often consumed by both humans and wildlife. It thrives in coastal areas and is commonly found in mangrove swamps and sandy soils. Due to its salt tolerance, it plays an important role in stabilizing coastal ecosystems.
